text:
Batik fails this test,

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="1.1">

  <style type="text/css">
    RECT { fill: red }
  </style>

  <rect id="test" fill="green" width="100" height="100" />

</svg>

As XML is case-sensitive the element type names in selectors are, too.
creator: bjoern@hoehrmann.de
deweese@apache.org
text:
I agree for SVG, from Section 5.1 of the CSS2 Spec:

   "The case-sensitivity of document language element names in 
    selectors depends on the document language. For example, 
    in HTML, element names are case-insensitive, but in XML 
    they are case-sensitive."

I will fix this shortly.

BTW any idea of psuedo element selectors should follow
document element selectors as to case sensitivity or
should they be considered CSS and hence case insensitive? ;)
creator: deweese@apache.org

text: The name of pseudo-elements is indeed case-insensitive.
creator: bjoern@hoehrmann.de

text:
Thanks!
This is now fixed in CVS.
